Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Automatic Sediment Core Analysis System to Enhance the Paleomagnetic and Rock Magnetic Laboratory at New Mexico Highlands University
Award.AbstractNarration:
1337123
Petronis

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant supports acquisition of an automated susceptibility core logging system and a field free-space. The equipment will support a range of paleoclimatological investigations on core material already collected from the Central High Plain aquifer and regional paleosols and modern soils. The equipment will complement existing paleomagnetic equipment at this minority serving undergraduate institution and support student experiential learning with modern techniques in paleomagnetic analysis and data interpretation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of the past four years we  developed a magnetostratigraphy for the first of the High Plains-Ogallala Drilling Project cores, HP1-A, and we are currently analyzing the remaining four cores obtained in the summer of 2014 as well as the outcrop samples obtained in summer 2014. The initial strategy used to sample the core was to scan all of the core segments that had been retrieved using an ASC Core Analysis System with a Bartington Instruments MS2C magnetic susceptibility coil. Portions of the core segments that had high relative magnetic susceptibility were then sampled as ~1.5 cm3 cube samples, solidified with sodium silicate. These samples were treated with alternating field demagnetization techniques as well as standard rock magnetism experiments, including isothermal remanent magnetization, saturation isothermal remanent magnetization and anhysteresis of remanent magnetization experiments. The initial set of samples yield promising results of four behaviors: 1) normal polarity of relatively steep inclination, 2) reverse polarity of steep inclination, 3) shallow inclination of normal and reverse polarity, and 4) unstable demagnetization behavior. The core segments were not oriented during drilling and so declination values are random. From this first set, a skeletal magnetostratigraphy was constructed for the parts of the core that were sampled (to a depth of 57 m). In the spring of 2014, gaps in this previous sampling effort were addressed by a high-density sampling effort wherein a 1.5 cm3 sample was obtained every meter or less from segments of the core skipped in the previous sampling effort and the remainder of the core below 57 m was also sampled. The second sets of samples are currently undergoing alternating field demagnetization experiments and should be completed next year.

In July 2014, we conducted field work in western Kansas collecting surface exposures of the Ogallala aquifer sediments to compare and possibility correlate to the subsurface sediments.  Undergraduate students are continuing to benefit from analysis of laboratory samples as well as participating in field studies. The new automatic core track system (funded by NSF – MRI awarded to PI Petronis) arrived in late September 2014 and we have analyzed all remaining four subsurface cores from the Ogallala in western Kansas.

On 18th September 2014, the drillers finished up the Norton County well and recovered 93 ft of, surprisingly, mostly very fine sand and clay with a 16 ft ash layer starting at 67 ft.  On the 19th September 2014, drilling began in Scott Country, just west of the Battle Canyon monument.  They hit the Ogallala Formation at 25 ft, about 30 or so feet higher than the canyon edge.  They drilled until they hit Cretaceous shale around 120 ft.  The remaining two wells were completed in mid-October.  In mid November, Dr. Jon Smith from the Kansas Geological Survey delivered the cores NMHU. Over the next three months, we completed the bulk susceptibility measurements of the four core samples, transport them back to the Kansas Geological Survey in March 2015, and sub sampled the cores at the Kansas Geological Survey, and returned the samples to the NMHU paleomagnetism laboratory. Analysis is currently underway at the NMHU lab.
